# Julie Hendry

> Interim and fractional CIO. FBCS, FRSA, MSc Psychology. Thirty years of technology transformation at scale across government, financial services, life sciences, and media.

## About

Julie Hendry is a technology executive with over thirty years of experience in technology transformation. She is a Fellow of the British Computer Society (FBCS), Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts (FRSA), and holds an MSc in Psychology (Distinction) from the University of Strathclyde and a BSc in Computer Studies from Glasgow Caledonian University. She has completed executive programmes at Oxford (AI), Columbia (Data Science), and MIT (Quantum Computing).

She is available for interim and fractional CIO positions, taking full ownership of technology estates with direct board accountability. Her approach starts with people and organisational diagnosis before prescribing solutions.

## Experience

- VP Global Engineering, Abcam (life sciences unicorn, £260M revenue): architecture, delivery, engineering, and operations across UK, China, US, and EU. Unlocked double-digit growth through Oracle Cloud ERP, MuleSoft API-led architecture (50+ APIs), and AWS migration (40% cost reduction).
- Group Director, Travis Perkins (FTSE 250): built software delivery across 200 people in UK and Ukraine. Led evacuation of 100 team members during Ukraine conflict while maintaining delivery continuity.
- CEO, Cybersafe Schools: platform helping schools protect children online.
- GDS, Cabinet Office: eliminated paper driving licences for 60 million users, saving £15M annually. Authored "Governance principles for agile service delivery," adopted across UK government.
- ESFA: delivered the digital Apprenticeship Levy, saving £2.7 billion annually.
- HMRC: agile delivery and DevOps across the £23 billion Aspire programme.
- Earlier career across JP Morgan, BBC, Sungard, American Express, Barclays, Tesco, Sky, The Guardian, and Royal London.

## Research

CTO of Beò (beo.llc), a research practice focused on digital wellbeing, the attention economy, and organisational performance. Her MSc research found that "addiction" scores showed weak correlation with actual social media screen time, leading to a focus on digital flourishing rather than pathology-based approaches.
